metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee solves untimed math problems in the following domains: basic concepts, everyday applications, geometry, and algebra.

questions.title: Item 1
questions.incorrectInstructionsHTML:
Incorrect response:

Score the item 0 points and say, Ready? Watch me.

Say, One, as you hold up one finger; then say, Two, as you hold up the second finger. Keeping both fingers raised, say, How many fingers am I holding up?
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say, Ready? Watch me.

Say, One, as you hold up one finger; then say, Two, as you hold up the second finger. Keeping both fingers raised, say, How many fingers am I holding up?

questions.title: Item 2
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the circle.

questions.title: Item 3
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the empty glass.

questions.title: Item 4
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, This time there are no pictures. Just watch me. Raise three fingers, one at a time, without counting them, and say, How many fingers am I holding up?

questions.title: Item 5
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the number 9.

questions.title: Item 6
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the number 5.

questions.title: Item 7
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say, This time there are no pictures. Let's count to six. I'll start and then you go on. Remember, count to six. Ready? One, two, three... what comes after three?

Do not penalize for counting beyond six.

questions.title: Item 8
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the hand holding the most balloons.

questions.title: Item 9
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many wagons are there?

questions.title: Item 10
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the longest line.

questions.title: Item 11
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the number 2 and say, What is this number?

questions.title: Item 12
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the triangle.

questions.title: Item 13
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Count aloud all the chips and tell me how many there are.

questions.title: Item 14
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which number is less? Encourage the examinee to touch the screen.

questions.title: Item 15
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which two hands have the same number of balloons?

questions.title: Item 16
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the number 7 and say, What is this number?

questions.title: Item 17
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Point to the number 10 and say, What is this number?

questions.title: Item 18
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, A group of students were asked which toys they liked best. This graph shows the choices of the students. Point to each row as you name the toy: Some students chose bears. Some chose bikes. Others chose balls. Each toy equals one student. How many students like the bears best?

questions.title: Item 19
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which number is more? Encourage the examinee to touch the screen.

questions.title: Item 20
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which number is less? Encourage the examinee to touch the screen.

questions.title: Item 21
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Use your hand to cover up three birds. How many birds are left uncovered?

questions.title: Item 22
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many shapes in all? Point in a circular motion across the entire page.

questions.title: Item 23
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch the second apple from the bowl.

questions.title: Item 24
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If you are counting in order, which of these numbers would you say first?

questions.title: Item 25
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many inches long is the pencil?

questions.title: Item 26
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If you are counting in order, which of these numbers would you say first?

questions.title: Item 27
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, And which of these numbers would come next?

questions.title: Item 28
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If two of these ducks flew away, how many would be left?

questions.title: Item 29
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If all the dots on the line had numbers, what number would go here? Point to the A.

questions.title: *Item 30
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, On what day of the week is the 14th?

questions.title: Item 31
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Neal had five marbles and was given three more. How many marbles does Neal have now?

questions.title: Item 32
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, These beads form a pattern on the pegs. How many beads should be put on the empty peg to complete this pattern?

questions.title: Item 33
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many pennies does it take to equal the value of one dime?

questions.title: Item 34
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, This graph shows the number of books given to the city library by students from four different schools. Going across the bottom of the graph, the schools are (point to each bar as you name the school) Central, Johnson, West, and Eastman. The numbers on the side (point to the y-axis) show the number of books given by each school. How many books did Eastman School give?

questions.title: Item 35
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What number goes here (point to the empty circle)?

questions.title: Item 36
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What time is shown on this clock?

questions.title: Item 37
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which is worth more: seven pennies, six nickels, or one quarter?

questions.title: Item 38
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, This graph shows the number of people who rode each fair ride. The rides were (point to each bar as you name the ride) the Ferris wheel, roller coaster, merry-go-round, water slide, pirate ship, and train. The numbers on the side (point to the y-axis) show the number of people who rode each ride. How many people rode the Ferris wheel? Point to Ferris wheel.

questions.title: Item 39
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which number is in the tens place?

questions.title: Item 40
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which number is in the hundred-thousands place?

questions.title: Item 41
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Robert has six toys. Together Robert and Max have 15 toys. How many toys does Max have?

questions.title: Item 42
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If you flipped a coin 10 times, how many times would you expect the coin to land on heads?

questions.title: Item 43
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Mrs. Rivera served cake for dessert. She cut the cake into six equal pieces. If Carlos eats two pieces and Jenna eats one piece, what fraction of the cake would be left?

questions.title: Item 44
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, A classroom has four rows of desks. Each row has the same number of desks. There are a total of 24 desks. How many desks are in each row?

questions.title: Item 45
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If today is the 3rd of the month, and Anita's cousin will come to visit on the 17th, how many weeks must Anita wait until her cousin arrives?

questions.title: Item 46
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, If you cut a cake into six equal pieces, what fraction of the cake would each piece be?

questions.title: Item 47
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which choice (sweep finger across answer choices) shows what this triangle (point to the top triangle) will look like if the graph paper is rotated 90 degrees to the right?

questions.title: Item 48
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Touch or say these fractions in order from smallest to largest.

questions.title: Item 49
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Find the perimeter in meters.

questions.title: Item 50
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What is the next number in this pattern? Point to the "?" in the pattern.

questions.title: Item 51
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Assuming angle A is 90 degrees and angle B is 20 degrees, what is the number of degrees in angle C?

questions.title: Item 52
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Kurt went to sleep at 10:30 p.m. and woke up at 7:00 a.m. the next morning. How long did Kurt sleep?

questions.title: Item 53
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Paul has scores of 95, 80, 85, and 80 on his first four math tests. What is his average test score?

questions.title: Item 54
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which choice (sweep finger across answer choices) shows what this figure (point to the top figure) will look like if the graph paper is rotated 180 degrees?

questions.title: Item 55
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Mary had 200 dollars. Then she bought four tires. Each tire cost 35 dollars and 50 cents, plus 3 dollars each for balancing. How much money did she have left?

questions.title: Item 56
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which decimal is closest in value to 5/6?

questions.title: Item 57
questions.topInstructionsHTML: This pie chart shows the money made by each booth at a fair. Which booth raised exactly 90 dollars?

questions.title: Item 58
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, The charity drive reached one-fourth of its goal in March, one-third of its goal in April, and one-sixth of its goal in May. What part of the goal was reached during these three months?

questions.title: Item 59
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What is the solution to this problem?

questions.title: *Item 60
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, Of these numbers, which ones are prime numbers?

questions.title: Item 61
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, A bank charges a monthly fee of eight dollars. You may write 20 checks a month for free. After 20 checks, you are charged 30 cents for each additional check you write. What will your charges be for a month in which you write 40 checks?

questions.title: Item 62
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, How many different kinds of sandwiches can Kevin make using one kind of bread, one kind of meat, and one kind of cheese? For his sandwich, Kevin can choose from two types of bread, two types of meat, and two types of cheese.

questions.title: Item 63
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, What is the maximum number of two inch by two inch pieces that can be cut from a 10 inch by 8 inch cake?

questions.title: Item 64
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, The Carver baseball team bought 10 dozen candy bars at 3 dollars and 75 cents per dozen. They sold the candy as a money-making project for 50 cents per bar. What was their profit?

questions.title: Item 65
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, What are the mean, median, and mode for these test scores?

questions.title: Item 66
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, What are the slope and y-intercept for the red line?

questions.title: Item 67
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, To answer this question, you may wish to use one or more of these formulas (point to formulas). If this ball were to roll exactly 100 complete revolutions, approximately how far would it travel in inches?

questions.title: Item 68
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, Jessica is mowing the lawn with a mower that has a 30-inch wide cut. If her lawn is 100 feet by 50 feet, what is the fewest number of trips needed, from one end to the other, to complete the job?

questions.title: Item 69
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Say, What is the probability that both spinners will stop on blue on the first spin?

questions.title: Item 70
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many different ways are there to arrange four books on a shelf?

questions.title: Item 71
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Scuba Bob is planning to dive to a depth of 60 feet, and his scuba tanks will last 19.5 minutes while on the surface. Assuming Scuba Bob can safely descend and rise to the surface at 2 feet per second, and at a depth of 60 feet he uses 10% more air, how many minutes can he safely stay on the bottom?

questions.title: Item 72
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, To answer this question, you may wish to use one or more of these formulas (point to formulas). Assume that each unit of the grid is two inches by two inches and only paths that do not pass through a red square are possible. What is the shortest distance between point A and point B? Round your answer to the nearest inch.

consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.description: This subtest discontinues after 4 consecutive scores of 0 points.
